body:
> > Please add sentence or two regarding:
> > Time column is optional in REFRESH use cases, but mandatory in APPEND use cases. You can add references to the table config seciton here.
> > How time column is used by broker to split between realtime and offline. I am nor sure if this belongs in the schema section, or a pointer to this belongs here. For now, if you can just add it here, we can figure out how to move it around. If you can find a better place that is fine as well.
> 
> I'll add a sentence on refresh/append use case. However, I don't think the other part about broker splitting between realtime/offline (and retention for that matter) belong here. There is some mention of that in Table Config section, already.

Oh good. In that case just add a ref to the table config section for how time column is used during query federation. I think it is useful to cross-reference things to encourage people to go to more than one section as needed. thanks
@fx19880617 I think you forgot to remove the import lol...

> The reason why we do not check if table exists is because when the previous table delete failed in the middle, the ideal state might already be removed. We still want to clean up the other properties for the table.

Thanks for pointing this out. Is it a common case? We could solve this issue in a periodically validation cleaner task?

> I'm still looking into this issue of POSTing data.
> Meanwhile there is a workaround by dumping the schema into a file and upload the schema file.
> Below is an example code snippet in python:
> 
> ```python
> import json
> temp_schema_path='/tmp/sample_schema.json'
> schema_payload = { "schemaName": "transcript", "dimensionFieldSpecs": [ { "name": "studentID", "dataType": "STRING" }, { "name": "firstName", "dataType": "STRING" }, { "name": "lastName", "dataType": "STRING" }, { "name": "gender", "dataType": "STRING" }, { "name": "subject", "dataType": "STRING" } ], "metricFieldSpecs": [ { "name": "score", "dataType": "FLOAT" } ] }
> 
> with open(temp_schema_path, 'w') as fp:
>     json.dump(schema_payload, fp)
> 
> 
> import requests
> url_origin = "http://localhost:9000/schemas"
> with open(temp_schema_path, 'rb') as f:
>     r = requests.post(url_origin, files={'sample_schema.json': f})
>     print(r.status_code)
> ```

Now I can able to upload the schema through API itself.. Thanks a lot @fx19880617

> > The reason why we do not check if table exists is because when the previous table delete failed in the middle, the ideal state might already be removed. We still want to clean up the other properties for the table.
> 
> Thanks for pointing this out. Is it a common case? We could solve this issue in a periodically validation cleaner task?

That is not the common case, but in exception path. Yes, that can be achieved by a periodically validation, but automatically delete table properties could also be risky. Right now we still rely on manually call the delete table again to clean up all properties.
Any reason why you want to check the table existence first?

> Why do we need to maintain a record level bitmap? That can easily cause memory issue (everything on heap).
> If we want to preserve `null` value, we should remove the NullValueTransformer from the record reader and let the record reader insert `null` into the GenericRow. The segment creator/mutable segment should be able to directly process `null` value.
> 

The bitmap added to Generic Row inside NullValueTransformer is a transient object (short lived) - which shouldn't cause any memory concern. 

However, I was maintaining a bitmap per docId inside MutableSegmentImpl. I've optimized that part of the code - its no longer necessary to keep track of all these bitmaps in memory.

> @icefury71 Thanks for the reply. LGTM assuming that you address the comments above (2 spaces, comment on bloom filter etc). I will merge this once that part is updated.
> 

I've reformatted code based on Pinot style.

I'm still against storing the bitmap into the GenericRecord because that will couple the presence vector with the NullValueTransformer (real-time segment generation does not use NullValueTransformer, thus it won't work properly).
Instead, we should just allow null values (missing fields) in the GenericRecord when it is passed to the SegmentCreator, then it becomes much more flexible, and we can choose to fill in default values, or add them into the presence vector.

> I'm still against storing the bitmap into the GenericRecord because that will couple the presence vector with the NullValueTransformer (real-time segment generation does not use NullValueTransformer, thus it won't work properly).

By real-time I'm assuming you mean either HLC / LLC realtime segments ? From code inspection it does look like we're using NullValueTransformer in real-time path:

https://github.com/apache/incubator-pinot/blob/master/pinot-core/src/main/java/org/apache/pinot/core/data/manager/realtime/LLRealtimeSegmentDataManager.java#L1158

(this is calling CompositeTransformer.getDefaultTransformer which in turn brings in NullValueTransformer)

> Instead, we should just allow null values (missing fields) in the GenericRecord when it is passed to the SegmentCreator, then it becomes much more flexible, and we can choose to fill in default values, or add them into the presence vector.

We considered this option. However, the problem is that it's extremely difficult to identify default null value which is outside the domain of legitimate values. In many cases there could be an overlap.

Given that memory is not a big concern, this could be a good way out. Thoughts ?

Did a rebase against master to resolve conflicts.

The record reader you mentioned is for ingesting data into real-time. When we convert real-time segment into offline segment, we use the RealtimeSegmentConverter which does not perform any transform on the records as records should already be in the desired format.
The concern is more about module isolation, meaning SegmentCreator interface should not expect the GenericRow to have a field of bitmap.
> 
> We considered this option. However, the problem is that it's extremely difficult to identify default null value which is outside the domain of legitimate values. In many cases there could be an overlap.

I don't quite follow. The logic should be very straight forward. If we allow null value, put the null value into the presence vector; if not, throw exception

> > > The reason why we do not check if table exists is because when the previous table delete failed in the middle, the ideal state might already be removed. We still want to clean up the other properties for the table.
> > 
> > 
> > Thanks for pointing this out. Is it a common case? We could solve this issue in a periodically validation cleaner task?
> 
> That is not the common case, but in exception path. Yes, that can be achieved by a periodically validation, but automatically delete table properties could also be risky. Right now we still rely on manually call the delete table again to clean up all properties.
> Any reason why you want to check the table existence first?

The reason is to existence check is to make sure the returned message does not show successful deletion of an non-existent table. This is also consistent with the other similar API DropTable() which does a table existence check.

The main purpose of this PR is to add unit test coverage. I did not know you also rely on this API to clear up some remaining metadata -- it is a minor but important use case i guess. I propose we at least modify the return message for the case of non-existent table: something along the line like "WARNING: table name does not exist. Delete table successfully".
I agree we should keep all APIs in sync. When the table does not exist, let's still delete the table properties, then throw the NOT_FOUND exception.

> I agree we should keep all APIs in sync. When the table does not exist, let's still delete the table properties, then throw the NOT_FOUND exception.

Make sense and this is probably the best solution currently. Revised the PR and please take another look.

Added a JMH Benchmark in the last commit. Simulated the logic in ``CombineGroupByOperator`` and ``CombineGroupByOrderByOperator``. 4 segments inserting 100k records each, concurrently. ``BenchmarkCombineGroupBy``: 1. ``benchmarkConcurrentIndexedTableInCombineGroupBy`` - inserting into ConcurrentIndexedTable like in the PR code 2. ``benchmarkOriginalCombineGroupBy`` - inserting into ConcurrentHashMap like in the original CombineGroupByOperator Conclusions: 1. New code does at par/better in scenarios - No order by - Order by, but buffer is so large that resize never triggered Therefore, **we should be good to enable this with a large buffer, and it will work well for usecases which will never trigger the resize** 2. In the case where it didn’t work, the bottleneck is clearly resizing. So **we can now focus on optimizing the resize**

The bug #4652 occurs when segment download is ongoing in `goOnlineFromConsuming()`. The manager is in RETAINING state but the partition consumer thread ignores the manager's instruction to stop in `buildSegmentInternal()`.So I do not think moving to downloadAndReplace() for all case will solve the bug. The PR is a more defensive effort to cover such case. 

Recall that in #4652, the controller asks the server to KEEP its segment. Thus the server then proceeded to build the segment in the partitionConsumerThread. But this happen out side of the 
`goOnlineFromConsuming()`. Does #4546 change this behavior as well?

> We should just downloa and replace thesegment in all cases in the `goOnlineFromConsuming()` method.
> 
> The current implementation (the first one) assumes that it is a lot more expensive to download than to build. In general, (especially for high QPS use cases) we have seen that segment build is more expensive.
> 
> It also makes the code path simpler.
> 
> It should be more common for a segment to participate in the segment completion protocol than to get an online state transition while still consuming or catching up, so the code path should get hit less often, especially after PR 4546
This PR is split into multiple PRs and the one for TransformBlockDataFetcher: #4658
LGTM

@jackjlli Added more description in the commit & PR message
please fix  errors

> please fix errors

Fixed the build

> Also, for the benchmark number, why for several cases TOP 15k is faster than TOP 5k, which is then faster than TOP 500?

The code used in benchmark decided `capacity` and `bufferCapacity` entirely on the basis of `TOP`.  Capacity = Max(5 * TOP, 5k). As a result, more the TOP, lesser the number of resizes. That's why as TOP increased the performance improved. 
It has been since changed, to just have a very large `capacity`. We will focus on the optimization of resize after this PR is in.
I updated the commit to also handle errors better in _getAnomalies, since one case now entails calling it twice (Edit Alert Preview being called when current anomalies aren't yet loaded)

> > Also, for the benchmark number, why for several cases TOP 15k is faster than TOP 5k, which is then faster than TOP 500?

Thank you for the change! Congratulation on your first commit to Pinot code base :)
Can you please give me sometime. Adding caching on top of ZK is not trivial and in the end we will end up implementing Helix caching code in Pinot.

Any kind of cache will always never be consistent when readers and writers are in different process/nodes. 

Instead of trying to achieve that, we should make sure our code is designed to handle the inconsistency gracefully

@chenboat That's a good point but Pinot should be able to reconnect and resume operations after the GC. Looks like some issue with Helix in handling ZK disconnect/re-connect
After some research, will try out the DataSketches (https://datasketches.github.io) library and evaluate its performance.

@chenboat , yes we see full GC at the Pinot-server when we run expensive queries and it is getting timeout with zookeeper which is expected . Issue here is the pinot-server goes for a toss and it stops responding completely until we manually restart the pinotserver. We are unable to access any of the tables due to this. we also have query timeout set at server and at the broker level. Do you suggest any fix to reconnect with zookeeper and resume the operations as usual when there is a full GC.

@Jackie-Jiang 
We haven't evaluated all of the above HLL variants, but we have a detailed comparison of the DataSketches HllSketch vs the Clearspring HLL++ implementation on our website:

[https://datasketches.github.io/docs/HLL/Hll_vs_Hllpp.html](https://datasketches.github.io/docs/HLL/Hll_vs_Hllpp.html) 

There is also a detailed discussion about measuring sketch performance in general that might be helpful.

https://github.com/apache/incubator-pinot/issues/4450
LGTM. Thanks for the fix!

@arthuersundar Did you see any re-connection events by Helix in the Pinot server log? That may help to clarify if Helix (ZKHelixManager) ever tried to reconnect.

Speaking of full GC, we also found another issue in #4484. In such events, the Pinot cluster may not serve queries well as we observed. In particular brokers could still send query to GC'ed servers. The recommendation on that issue is to have a GC triggered auto restart -- if your team have such mechanism in place, then auto-restart could be a choice.

> LGTM. Just curious how we handle consuming(mutable) segment after adding the default value to the schema.

@jackjlli Good point - it remains an issue. The consuming segment would have the old schema, while previously committed segments would get the new schema after the reload.

As a result, if the user queries the newly added field (or select *) between the reload and the consuming segment is committed, some segments (either the consuming segment or all other segments, most likely the former) would be dropped from the query result.

This diff is part of the efforts to fully address the schema evolution story. Slack channel in apache-pinot is #feat-better-schema-evolution if you are interested.

Sounds like a great idea!

I have asked @npawar  to look at the class from the standpoint of:
- What if an exception is raised where we would have returned a boolean 'false' before. It seemed like we would continue to do what we can, but now we abort.
- Log messages: Used to be that every step is logged, so that we can reconstruct what happened during a repair or segment assignment. It will help in reasoning about  problems like : "this segment was not repaired", "this partition stopped consuming". With the removal of logs, we need to be careful that we clearly log an exception that may have happened while we try to do an operation, or otherwise log the branches that we may take that may lead us to NOT completing an operation.
